titlestmt.titleproper:
Society of Daughters of Holland Dames Records
1895-2015
MS 3034
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Joseph Ditta

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2018-02-08T13:23-0500

did.unittitle: Society of Daughters of Holland Dames records
did.abstract: Records of the still-active Society of Daughters of Holland Dames, Descendants of the Ancient and Honorable Families of New Netherland, a lineage organization open solely to women of Dutch or New Netherland descent. The Holland Dames support Dutch culture and history, and to that end have erected memorials in New York City, notably stained glass windows to Peter Stuyvesant at St. Mark's Church-in-the-Bowery (1903), and to Henry Hudson at the New-York Historical Society (1908). Includes board minutes, financial records, some correspondence, and ephemera.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Society of Daughters of Holland Dames.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Society of Daughters of Holland Dames, Descendants of the Ancient and Honorable Families of New Netherland (hereafter “Holland Dames”), was organized on 8 May 1895 and incorporated 9 December 1895 “to perpetuate the memory and promote the principles and virtues of the Dutch ancestors of its members” by collecting and preserving “genealogical and historical documents relating to the Dutch in America,” encouraging “excellence in historical research,” and establishing “commemorative and durable memorials in lasting tribute to the early Dutch settlers.” Similar in aim to the males-only Holland Society of New York (established 1885), the Holland Dames membership is open solely to women over the age of eighteen who can prove descent from an ancestor, male or female, who was born in the Netherlands or New Netherland prior to the 1674 Treaty of Westminster (when the Dutch ceded control of the region to the English), or whose ancestor resided in New Netherland prior to the Treaty of Westminster, or whose ancestor held some official capacity in New Netherland (e.g., a Director General; a member of the Director General’s council; a member of a governmental or religious body; a patroon or freeholder; a commissioner of Indian Affairs, boundaries, or treaties; or a commissioned officer, soldier, or sailor who served in defense of New Netherland).

In fulfillment of their goals the Holland Dames have placed Dutch-specific monuments around New York City, most notably at St. Mark’s Church-in-the-Bowery, where a stained glass window to Peter Stuyvesant (1610-1672), last Director General of New Netherland, was installed above his burial vault in 1903, and at the New-York Historical Society, where a stained glass window entitled “ Memorial to Henry Hudson: The Arrival of the Halve Maen, 1609,” was installed in the library in 1908. (The Holland Dames later funded the restoration of both windows.)

From 1915 through the 1990s the Holland Dames provided partial scholarships to American college students of Dutch ancestry. They have supported Dutch historic sites in New York City, such as the 18th-century Hendrick I. Lott House in Marine Park, Brooklyn, and the Brinckerhoff Cemetery, a colonial-era burial ground in Fresh Meadows, Queens. The Holland Dames have hosted visits of the Dutch royal family (by tradition its female members have been honorary Holland Dames), and participated in anniversary celebrations, such as the 2009 Henry Hudson Quadricentennial/NY400, in recognition of their Dutch ancestors.
The Holland Dames governing board is headed by its Directress General. Twenty-nine women have held that position through 2014:

bioghist.p: [Adapted from Society of Daughters of Holland Dames, Descendants of the Ancient and Honorable Families of New Netherland, List of Members and Associates with the Constitution and By-Laws, 2014-2015 (box 5, folder 2) and Maria A. Dering, Researching Your Dutch Ancestors: A Practical Guide, compiled for the Holland Dames in 2011 (N-YHS call no. E184.D9 D4 2011). For information on the current activities of the Holland Dames, visit www.hollanddames.org.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The records of the Society of Daughters of Holland Dames span 110 years, from the organization's founding in 1895 through 2015, when the collection was given to the New-York Historical Society. Each Holland Dames officer kept her own records, and reported the activities in her purview monthly or annually. As a result, and because the Society's records were never maintained in a central location, there are decided gaps in coverage. Despite this, the minutes of board and annual meetings provide the best documentation of the Holland Dames' activities and projects, some of which are further detailed in dedicated folders. See, for instance, the papers generated by the 1903 installation of a stained glass window to Peter Stuyvesant in St. Mark's Church-in-the-Bowery (box 9, folder 18), or the memorial to Society's communal Dutch ancestors proposed for Battery Park, and the ensuing litigation from its designer, sculptor Robert Aitken, who sued for payment (box 8, folder 12).

Although the collection includes membership registers and printed lists, it lacks the genealogical material supplied by Holland Dames members to prove their Dutch ancestry. Those papers remain in custody of the Holland Dames ( www.hollanddames.org).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is divided into the following series and subseries:

Series I. Governance, 1895-2015
Subseries I.A. Founding documents, 1895-2006
Subseries I.B. Board Meeting minutes, 1895-2013
Subseries I.C. Reports, 1898-2012
Subseries I.D. Membership, 1895-2015

Series II. Subject Files, 1892-2013
Subseries II.A. Meetings, luncheons, receptions, 1900-2013
Subseries II.B. Officers' files, 1919-2012 (bulk, 1992-2012)
Subseries II.C. Projects and general topics, 1896-2013
Subseries II.D. Talks & papers | delivered before the Society & elsewhere, 1892-2013
Subseries II.E. Artifacts, ca. 1898-1990s

Series III. Financial, 1896-2011
Subseries III.A. Treasurer's reports, correspondence, receipts, 1896-2011
Subseries III.B. Financial Statements & tax returns, 1964-2007
Subseries III.C. Banking and Investment records, 1938-2000
Subseries III.D. Miscellaneous financial records, 1898-1995

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to twenty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. (Researchers may not accrue unused copy amounts from previous days.)

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: This collection is owned by the New-York Historical Society. The copyright law of the United States governs the making of photocopies and protects unpublished materials as well as published materials. Unpublished materials created before 1 January 1978 cannot be quoted in publication without permission of the copyright holder.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation Note
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as Society of Daughters of Holland Dames Records, MS 3034, The New-York Historical Society.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Society of Daughters of Holland Dames, 2015.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Archivist Joseph Ditta processed this collection in December 2017-February 2018.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes the foundational documents of the Society of Daughters of Holland Dames: its certificate of incorporation (1895), printed constitutions and by-laws; meeting minutes of its governing board; annual reports mixed with scattered officers' reports; and membership registers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is divided into four subseries:

Subseries I.A. Founding documents, 1895-2006
Subseries I.B. Board Meeting minutes, 1895-2013
Subseries I.C. Reports, 1898-2012
Subseries I.D. Membership, 1895-2015

did.unittitle: Certificate of Incorporation, Constitution, By-Laws, Members (1-128) [bound volume]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a copy of a petition to the New York State Supreme Court (1909) to change the name of the organization from "Society of Daughters of Holland Dames, Descendants of the Ancient and Honorable Families of the State of New York" to "Society of Daughters of Holland Dames, Descendants of the Ancient and Honorable Families of New Netherland."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes annual reports, 1970-1974.

scopecontent.p: Lacks annual meetings, 1972-1973.

scopecontent.p: Includes annual report, 1985.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series pulls together varied documents that were stored in loose files and binders. They include correspondence, ephemera, some photographs, clippings, and general subject files relating to Holland Dames activities, events, interests, projects, and outings. The "officers' files" (bulk, 1992-2012), appear to have been assembled by Holland Dames board members, each of whom kept her own records as part of her duties. These include postal and email correspondence, invitations, ceremonial programs, drafts of board minutes, clippings, photographs, and ephemera, such as an orange handkerchief dated "09.09.09" given to invited guests to wave in celebration of the opening of the New Amsterdam Pavilion in Battery Park by Crown Prince (now King) Willem-Alexander of the Netherlands (see box 7, folder 13). The list of Holland Dames Directresses General in the historical note near the start of this finding aid may assist researchers wishing to interpret the material in the officers' files. A small collection of artifacts--largely medals depicting Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands--rounds out the series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II is divided into five subseries:

Subseries II.A. Meetings, luncheons, receptions, 1900-2013
Subseries II.B. Officers' files, 1919-2012 (bulk, 1992-2012)
Subseries II.C. Projects and general topics, 1896-2013
Subseries II.D. Talks & papers | delivered before the Society & elsewhere, 1892-2013
Subseries II.E. Artifacts, ca. 1898-1990s

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An orange silk or satin jewel box containing objects donated to the Daughters of Holland Dames by Mrs. Alexander Crawford Chenoweth (first Directress General) in 1925:

list.item: Miniature silver bracelet (or crown?), a memento from Queen Wilhelmina's wedding, 1901.
Medal (white metal) inscribed: "Wilhelmina Koningin der Nederlanden [obverse]"; "Ter Herinnering aan de Kroning Van H. M. Koningin Wilhelmina" [reverse], circa 1898-1925.
Medal (brown metal, with pendant loop at top) inscribed: "Wilhelmina Koningen der Ned." [obverse], circa 1898-1925.
Medal (brown metal, in a lapel pin mounting) inscribed: "Wilhelmina Koningen der Nederlanden" [obverse], circa 1898-1925.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bronze medal commemorating the silver jubilee (i.e., 25th anniversary) of the reign of Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands, inscribed "Wilhelmina Koningin der Nederlanden" [obverse] and "MDCCCXCVIII [1898] - MDCCCCXXIII [1923]" [reverse]. Donated by Mrs. Joseph F. Simmons, who in 1923 received this medal as the Holland Dames delegate to the jubilee.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bronze medal designed by Anna Vaughn Hyatt Huntington and produced by the Medallic Art Company in 1920. Inscribed "Woman's Roosevelt Memorial Association Service" [obverse] and "Theodore Roosevelt / Born October 27, 1858 / Died January 6, 1919" [reverse]. The New-York Historical Society holds another copy of this medal under INV.3562.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fabric samples for Holland Dames lapel pins.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains treasurer and accountant reports, bank statements and cancelled checks for the Holland Dames general and scholarship accounts, investment records, and the Society's IRS 990 form (1987-2007). In later years (1992-2011) the treasurer's reports devolve into informal gatherings of bank statements, receipts, paid bills, and correspondence.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series III is divided into four subseries:

Subseries III.A. Treasurer's reports, correspondence, receipts, 1896-2011
Subseries III.B. Financial Statements & tax returns, 1964-2007
Subseries III.C. Banking and Investment records, 1938-2000
Subseries III.D. Miscellaneous financial records, 1898-1995
